column1: - A cut is then made in the breastbone, which is moved to the correct location.
The surgeon may use a metal strut (support piece) to hold the breastbone in this normal position until it heals.
Sometimes the deformity is so severe that it causes chest pain and affects breathing, especially in adults.

Risks for anesthesia and surgery in general are: - Reactions to medicines - Breathing problems - Bleeding, blood clots, or infection Risks for this surgery are: - Injury to the heart - Lung collapse - Pain - Return of the deformity

The surgeon will order the following: - An electrocardiogram (ECG) and possibly an echocardiogram that shows how the heart is functioning - Pulmonary function tests to check for breathing problems - CT scan or MRI of the chest Tell your child's health care provider about: - Medicines your child is taking.

- Allergies your child may have to medicine, latex, tape, or skin cleanser During the days before the surgery: - About 7 days before surgery, your child may be asked to stop taking aspirin, ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin), naproxen (Aleve, Naprosyn), warfarin (Coumadin), and any other drugs that make it hard for blood to clot.
- The surgeon will make sure your child has no signs of illness before surgery.
After that, pain is usually managed with medicines taken by mouth.
Before leaving the hospital, you will receive a prescription for pain medicine for your child.
